title: Exhaust Catalytic Converter - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.

If the engine has recently been running, the exhaust components may be hot to the touch. Contact with the hot components may cause damage to exposed skin. To avoid skin damage, always allow the hot parts to cool before working on the exhaust system.
Always note the position and orientation of exhaust clamps prior to releasing them, and return them to the noted position and orientation on assembly.
Seat and Battery (Links) - remove D34; DD2; DD4; DE; DE2; DEX; DF; DF2; DF4; DG4

metadata.ModelsTaxonomyLink: D34; DD4; DG4; DF4; DEX; DD2; DF2; DE2; DF; DE

body.body: Exhaust intermediate and header pipe Removal DE2; DF2
Remove the exhaust intermediate and header pipes (see
Exhaust Intermediate and Header Pipes - Removal
Remove the fixing and move the front heat shield forward to detach it from its lower locating lugs and remove the heat shield. Collect the shouldered washer.
Remove the two fixings and rubber mountings securing the catalytic converter to its heat shield.
Manoeuvre the catalytic converter down and to the left hand side to disengage its locating lug from the right hand side of the heat shield.
Remove the catalytic converter from the motorcycle.
If required, remove the three fixings and remove the heat shield.

metadata.products: DG4; DF4; DD2; DF2; DF; DE2; DE
